awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: POGIL-PCL: Student learning in the laboratory through sustained faculty development
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will conduct Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning-Physical Chemistry Laboratory (POGIL-PCL) workshops for faculty, postdoctoral fellows, and graduate students. These workshops will be held around the country at a variety of higher education institutions. Additionally, there will be ongoing development of POGIL-PCL experiments, which will serve to engage returning and new faculty participants in sustaining the project. Student learning outcomes resulting from use of POGIL-PCL materials in the laboratory will be examined. Ultimately, the use of evidence-based student-centered active learning in the laboratory will be analyzed and promoted and the learning that students achieve in an active-learning laboratory setting will be characterized.

The project will examine the impact a connected community of faculty has on the sustained implementation of this methodology. The project will use social network theory to describe how the adoption of materials is affected by sustained interactions among faculty members after their initial introduction at a workshop.  A broad range of institutions will be engaged to reach new and established faculty, and to provide professional development opportunities for graduate students and post-doctoral fellows.  Knowledge surveys coupled to think-aloud interviews and adaptations of published instruments will be used to answer questions regarding students' perception of their learning and their understanding of physical chemistry phenomena as a function of participating in POGIL-PCL experiments.  Faculty teaching will be observed and characterized on the basis of facilitation and student engagement.  The survey and observational data will be analyzed, in part, through the lens of a theoretical framework for coordination of theory and evidence.

por.por_cntn:
POGIL-PCL (Process-Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning for the Physical Chemistry Laboratory) represents a community of over 200 instructors involved in the development and implementation of experiments for this course. POGIL-PCL also comprises a set of 21 completed experiments developed over two NSF-funding periods (2012-2014, 2017-2023) using POGIL principles that emphasize modeling of both macroscopic and microscopic chemical phenomena, student design and refinement of experimental protocols, and data pooling to assist in uncovering physical chemistry principles. Each experiment has multiple “data-think” cycles in which student teams begin by making predictions. The teams then design and implement experimental protocols to test their predictions, use the results (and guiding questions) to refine their understanding of the chemical systems, and identify and perform the next set of experiments that can deepen that understanding. Figure 1 illustrates the POGIL-PCL experiment cycle.

 

The most recent cycle of funding led to five publications in addition to a themed issue of the Journal of Chemical Education focused on teaching in the chemistry laboratory. Five of the 21 completed experiments are computational. Jupyter notebooks have been developed for three of the experiments that use Python coding for data analysis. We have also completed two community surveys. The most recent survey brought 102 responses out of an email list with 248 names. Results from this survey are included here.

 

A key feature of our work is our online and in-person workshops that create and support a community of experiment developers, authors, reviewers, and adopters. Both the in-person workshops and their online counterparts provide the experience of doing an experiment including teamwork, experiment design, and data analysis. Each of our workshops includes both new and experienced participants. Participants report in our yearly surveys a slight preference for face-to-face versus online workshops for their opportunity for connection and professional development, but the majority of survey respondents find all the workshops to have value (see figure below). 

 

Personal connections among participants is reported by survey participants as a reason for attending a workshop (67% attended a POGIL-PCL workshop based on a personal recommendation or after attending a POGIL-PCL seminar or BCCE workshop). Workshop participants ranked personal connections very highly: "networking" and "getting insight from colleagues on implementing and facilitating guided inquiry experiments in courses" were rated 8.2 and 8.3 (on average, from a scale from 1-10) by survey respondents. 

 

The effectiveness of POGIL-PCL workshops and experiments are illustrated in part by how often POGIL-PCL experiments are adopted. The next figure demonstrates which POGIL-PCL experiments have been implemented, as reported by survey respondents, along with which experiments were carried out by respondents in a workshop. The most adopted experiment ("Can we make stew with these beans?", informally referred to as "chickpeas") is used most frequently in our workshops; it is also the simplest to implement. The experiment "Are the molecules that make a solution red big or small?" (informally, "dyes") has been implemented by many participants although few have done the experiment in a workshop. The chickpeas experiment is not part of the traditional physical chemistry laboratory canon of experiments. In contrast, the dyes experiment is an experiment that is well-known as a verification experiment. The widespread adoption of the POGIL-PCL dyes experiment points to the strong interest in this alternative, inquiry-based version.

 

The effectiveness of the workshops and experiments is also reflected by the 85% of survey respondents who recommend POGIL-PCL to colleagues. Likewise, 76 respondents reported that POGIL-PCL had changed their teaching, including 64 respondents who attended workshops and implemented experiments and 12 respondents who attended workshops but did not implement experiments. 

 

We continue to explore other mechanisms for maintaining community: In 2023 we started monthly journal club discussions that have engaged over 40 different POGIL-PCL participants. We are also developing a data analysis workshop focused on Python coding within Jupyter notebooks. Experiment development continues with online discussions ongoing for experiments in the areas of quantum dots, surface science, systems modeling/greenhouse gases, and exploration of the (in)stability of HArF. We continue to give presentations and workshops at regional and national conferences like the 2024 spring national ACS meeting and the summer 2024 BCCE. We maintain a web-presence via our website, pogilpcl.org, as well as the PiPER physical chemistry website (https://chemistry.coe.edu/piper/).
